titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Martin H. Bush Papers, 1948-2012, bulk 1970- 2008, in the Archives of American Art aaa.bushmart
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Joy Goodwin

note.p: This finding aid is associated with a MARC collection-level record. 365832

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-06-23T14:49-0400

did.abstract: The papers of Martin H. Bush measure 4.1 linear feet and date from 1948-2012, with the bulk of the material dating from 1970-2008. The collection documents Bush's career as an art historian, educator, consultant, and gallery director through biographical material, correspondence, interviews, subject files, a scrapbook, and printed material.
did.langmaterial: Most of the collection is in English; some printed material is in German.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 6 series.

list.item: Series 1: Biographical Material, 1956-2008 (Box1, OV 5; 0.2 linear feet)

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Martin H. Bush (1932-) is an art historian, educator, consultant, and gallery director.

Bush received a Bachelor of Arts from the State University of New York at Albany in 1958. From 1963-1965, he taught at Syracuse University, where he earned his Ph.D in History in 1966. Bush also served as the University's Assistant Dean for Academic Resources from 1965-1970. During this time, Martin H. Bush was also a consultant to the New York State Education Department.

From 1970-1974, Martin H. Bush was the Vice President of Academic Resource Development at Wichita State University, a position created for him by the University's President, Clark Ahlberg. In this post, Bush established a special collections department at Ablah Library and the Ulrich Museum of Art. Bush was also a consultant to several major corporations in Wichita, including Fourth Financial Corporation, Range Oil Company, and American Diversified Real Estate. In 1974, in recognition of Bush's contribution to the museum, the University opened the Martin H. Bush Outdoor Sculpture Collection. Bush has been involved in the acquisition of major pieces of outdoor sculpture from such well-known artists as Chaim Gross, Barbara Hepworth, Henry Moore, Juan Mir√≥, Louise Nevelson, and George Rickey. In 1989, Bush moved to New York City, where he continued his work as an art consultant. From 1992-1993, he was President of the ACA Gallery.

Martin H. Bush has published many books and articles on artists as well as contributed essays for exhibition catalogs. In the 1970s-1980s, Bush interviewed major artists for public television and radio programs in Wichita, among them Benny Andrews, Isabel Bishop, Richard Pousette-Dart, and Theodoros Stamos. Martin H. Bush's honors and awards include the George S. Patton Medal by the government of Luxembourg for his essay, "Ben Shahn: The Passion of Sacco and Vanzetti," 1969; "Outstanding Educator" by the Kansas Art Education Association, 1979; and the Wichita Arts Council Award, 1984.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original material requires an appointment. Use of archival audiovisual recordings with no duplicate access copy requires advance notice.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Martin H. Bush papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated in 2013 by Martin H. Bush.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Martin H. Bush papers, 1948-2012, bulk 1970-2008. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The papers of Martin H. Bush measure 4.1 linear feet and date from 1948-2012, with the bulk of the material dating from 1970-2008. The collection documents Bush's career as an art historian, educator, consultant, and gallery director through biographical material, correspondence, interviews, subject files, a scrapbook, and printed material.

Biographical material includes curriculum vitae, a certificate of discharge from the United States Army Reserve, and a lifetime membership certificate from the Edwin A. Ulrich Museum of Art. Most of the correspondence is personal in nature and consists of letters between Bush and his colleagues at Wichita State University and the Ulrich Museum of Art, friends, and family members. Martin H. Bush's interviews on videocassette with artists and other figures in the art world include Benny Andrews, Duane Hanson, Ivan Karp, Alice Neel, Louise Nevelson, and Arnold Newman.

Subject files primarily document Martin H. Bush's activities as an art dealer and consultant and contain auction house sales and files on individual artists, including Richard Pousette-Dart, Robert Goodnough, Ernest Trova, and Isaac Witkin. Source files include illustrated letters by John Von Wicht and a folder on Samuel Beckett's correspondence with Bush that includes three holograph letters and one typescript letter from Beckett. A small amount of material references Bush's tenure as director of the ACA Gallery. Photographic materials are also included.

A scrapbook contains news clippings and excerpts of newsletters covering Bush's career at Wichita State University. Printed material includes books, an educational brochure, exhibition catalogs, and a memorial booklet.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: This collection was processed to a minimal level and a finding aid prepared in 2014 by Joy Goodwin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes a certificate of discharge from the United State Army Reserve, a membership certificate from the Edwin A. Ulrich Museum of Art, and a clipping detailing the significant artwork acquired by Bush for the Ulrich Museum. Biographical information provides an overview of Bush's professional activities and accomplishments as a consultant, an university arts administrator, educator, and art historian.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Biographical material is arranged by subject.

did.unittitle: Certificate of Discharge from the United States Army Reserve
Lifetime Membership Certificate from the Edwin A. Ulrich Museum of Art, Wichita State University (1992 January 24)
Oversized Certificate from the Edwin A. Ulrich Museum of Art, Wichita State University (1992 January 24), from Box 1, Folder 3

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence reflects Bush's activities as an independent consultant. Files also contain curriculum vitae, printed material, brochures, clippings, and appraisal of artwork. Correspondents include colleagues at Wichita State University, museum directors, curators, collectors, and friends. Letters between Bush and his friends discuss baseball, particularly Bush's interest in early twentieth century baseball players. Of interest, is correspondence between Martin H. Bush and Lois More Overbeck, co-editor of The Letters of Samuel Beckett; Overbeck was seeking permission to reprint the letters between Bush and Samuel Beckett. Also included are letters from Bush's wife, Jennie.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Correspondence is arranged in alphabetical order. Names with five or more letters are filed alphabetically by person or corporate name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes a thank you note from Ernest Trova

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of Bush's interviews with artists and prominent figures in the art world. Some of the interviews by Bush were conducted during his tenure as Director of the Ulrich Museum. Interviews are recorded on 12 videocassettes; some videorecordings include multiple interviews.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Additional interviews can also be found in Series 4: Subject Files. This series is arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes interviews with Benny Andrews, Arnold Newman, and Duane Hanson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes interview with Louise Nevelson, "Born Artist"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes files on Martin H. Bush's dealings with individual artists, mostly relating to exhibitions, some organized by Martin H. Bush and sales of artwork. There are extensive files on Richard Pousette-Dart, Robert Goodnough, Ernest Trova, and Isaac Witkin. Auction files document Bush's consulting projects for art institutions, such as Owensboro Museum of Art and the Ulrich Museum of Art as well as his activities as a collector. Files may include a variety of material, such as correspondence, drafts, memoranda, proposals, informational sheets, lists of artwork, inventory lists, condition reports, printed material, clippings and reviews, exhibition catalogs, annotated auction catalogs, and photographic materials, including slides and transparencies. Among the business-related materials are appraisals, price lists, sale sheets, bids, lists of deaccessioned artwork, consignment agreements, condition reports, receipts, and invoices. There is limited documentation relating to Bush's directorship at ACA Gallery.

Also found are Martin H. Bush's correspondence with Samuel Beckett, including three holograph letters and one typescript letter from Beckett; John Von Wicht's illustrated letters; and an annotated typescript of Bush's account of his initial meeting with Joan Mir√≥. Other source files include a list of scholars conducting research for catalogue raisonn√© projects, obituary notices on friends and acquaintances, and the Ulrich Museum of Art, particularly the museum's twentieth-fifth anniversary celebration. Two videorecordings of an ESPN "Up Close" Interview and and ESPN Hall of Fame induction ceremony reflect Bush's interest in baseball.
Subject files include 11 videocassettes and 1 electronic disc (DVD).

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Files are arranged by subject and thereafter in alphabetical order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A scrapbook of news clippings provides an account of Bush's activities and accomplishments at the Ulrich Museum of Art. Also found are two letters and a few photographs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Although the volume has been dismantled, its original order is retained.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The small amount of printed material in the collection includes a book of biographical entries on artists, exhibition catalogs, and a memorial booklet on Philip Reisman. Included are inscribed publications, two from Abraham Walkowitz and one from Kenzo Okada. An educational brochure, The Birth of a Song by Martin H. Bush provides historical background to the writing of "The Star Spangled Banner."

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: AThis series is arranged by format.
